prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The procedural treatment of tag-along actions is discussed in detail in § 4:6. Rules 7.1 & 7.2 of the Panel Rules govern tag-along actions, and permit the Clerk of the Panel to enter conditional transfer orders in these actions upon learning of the pendency of the related action.[1] If no party files a notice of objection to the conditional transfer order within 7 days of its entry, the conditional transfer order will become final and will be filed with the clerk of the transferee court.[2] If a notice of objection is filed and is followed by a timely motion to vacate the conditional transfer order, the matter will be treated by the Panel as any other case involving the question of transfer and the parties will be afforded the opportunity to brief and argue the transfer question.[3] The question of transfer will be decided by the panel on the merits even if the parties do not respond to objections to transfer. In one case the Panel ordered transfer of a tag-along action over the objection of a party served with a conditional transfer order despite the fact that none of the other parties responded to that party's objections to transfer.[4]

The Clerk of the Panel may alternatively enter an Order to Show Cause why transfer should not be ordered.[5] This procedure is generally used where the Panel reasonably anticipates that at least one party will object to the conditional transfer order and will seek a hearing. The order to show cause procedure is more expeditious in that circumstance.

The Panel Rules require all parties to advise the Panel of any potential tag-along actions in which that party is named.[6] The Panel can also order a party to advise the Panel of all potential tag-along actions.[7]

The most misunderstood feature of tag-along action practice relates to the conditional transfer order and order to show cause. These orders are routinely entered by the Clerk of the Panel and do not create any presumption as to how the Panel will decide the transfer question on the merits. If objections are filed in a timely manner, the matter will be considered by the Panel on the merits, and the earlier conditional transfer order or order to show cause will not affect its decision.[8] The Panel has denied transfer of potential tag-along actions despite its prior entry of a conditional transfer order[9] and order to show cause.[10] The Panel has pointed out when denying to transfer that the parties are free to seek transfer in the future if the nature of the litigation warrants it.[11]

Despite the fact that neither a conditional transfer order nor order to show cause creates a true presumption in favor of transfer, the parties to an action receiving the order need to understand that the odds are strongly in favor of transfer. The Panel repeatedly states that tag-along actions are being transferred for the same reasons that transfer was ordered when the docket was created.[12]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
